G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19\u201319A.proposition: This action is brought in the Worcester District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–19A and G.L. c. 212, § 3, because the amount in controversy does not exceed the jurisdictional limits of this Court and involves a claim for personal injuries arising under Massachusetts law.

G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3.proposition: This action is brought in the Worcester District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–19A and G.L. c. 212, § 3, because the amount in controversy does not exceed the jurisdictional limits of this Court and involves a claim for personal injuries arising under Massachusetts law.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Worcester District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2, because the cause of action arose in Worcester County and the Property that is the subject of this action is located at 123 Maple Street, Worcester, Massachusetts 01603.

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition: At all times relevant, Defendant owed all lawful visitors to the Property, including business invitees and lawful visitors such as Plaintiff, a duty of reasonable care to maintain the walkways and sidewalk in a reasonably safe condition, and to take reasonable steps to protect such persons against foreseeable hazards, including snow and ice accumulations.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly holds that property owners owe to all lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care with respect to hazards from snow and ice, applying the same standard that governs all other premises hazards. It specifically rejects the prior ‘natural vs. unnatural accumulation’ limitation and reaffirms that a property owner must act reasonably to maintain walkways and similar areas in a reasonably safe condition for lawful visitors, which matches the proposition stated.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We now abolish the distinction between natural and unnatural accumulations of snow and ice, and apply to all hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation of reasonable care that a property owner owes to lawful visitors regarding all other hazards.” … “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances….’”

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.proposition: At all times relevant, Defendant owed all lawful visitors to the Property, including business invitees and lawful visitors such as Plaintiff, a duty of reasonable care to maintain the walkways and sidewalk in a reasonably safe condition, and to take reasonable steps to protect such persons against foreseeable hazards, including snow and ice accumulations.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the leading Massachusetts case abolishing the invitee/licensee distinction and imposing a general duty of reasonable care owed by landowners/occupiers to all lawful visitors. While the provided excerpt is only a concurrence focusing on the trespasser issue, the main opinion holds that occupiers owe lawful entrants a duty of reasonable care in maintaining premises, which encompasses conditions such as snow and ice on walkways. Thus, as to lawful visitors and business invitees, the case supports the stated duty of reasonable care, though not specifically limited to snow and ice.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a "licensee" rather than an "invitee," or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors.

See *Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 14.proposition: The hazardous icy condition on the sidewalk was not open and obvious to Plaintiff under the circumstances, and, even if it were, Defendant was still required to take reasonable steps in light of the foreseeable risk of harm.
See *Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 14.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the open and obvious doctrine and the Restatement §343A exception. It holds that even where a dangerous condition is open and obvious, a landowner may still owe a duty to remedy that danger if he can and should anticipate that lawful entrants will encounter it despite its obviousness. Although the facts involve a trampoline and pool rather than ice on a sidewalk, the court expressly relies on and extends the same Papadopoulos/Soederberg icy-walkway line of cases, confirming that open and obvious conditions (including icy ones) may still require reasonable remedial steps when harm is foreseeable.
See *Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 14.relevant_excerpt: “A landowner, though, ‘is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] “can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the [lawful visitor] notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.”’ Papadopoulos, supra, quoting Soederberg… Having established that the existence of an open and obvious danger will not necessarily relieve a landowner of all duties… we set out to answer… in what circumstances will the duty to remedy nevertheless exist….”

See *Deignan v. Lubarsky*, 318 Mass. 661.raw_text: See *Deignan v. Lubarsky*, 318 Mass. 661 (1945); *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165 (1973).
See *Deignan v. Lubarsky*, 318 Mass. 661.proposition: Defendant knew or, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have known of the icy and dangerous condition of the sidewalk, particularly after receiving complaints and photographs from tenants, and thus had actual and/or constructive notice of the hazard.
See *Deignan v. Lubarsky*, 318 Mass. 661.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns an employer’s liability for a worker’s fall from a roof and turns entirely on whether violation of a safety regulation (failure to provide roof staging) was a causal factor in the accident. It does not discuss icy or dangerous sidewalk conditions, premises liability standards, or actual/constructive notice based on complaints or photographs. Therefore it does not provide authority for the proposition about a defendant’s notice of an icy sidewalk hazard.
See *Deignan v. Lubarsky*, 318 Mass. 661.relevant_excerpt: “To recover, the plaintiff was required to prove negligence on the part of the defendant that contributed to cause the death of her intestate… It is true that the violation of a penal statute or of a valid ordinance, rule or regulation is evidence of negligence as to all consequences that were intended to be prevented… But… ‘Negligence consisting in whole or in part of violation of law, like other negligence, is without legal consequence unless it is a contributing cause of the injury.’ … The evidence would not warrant a finding that the violation of Rule 6… bore any causal relation to the death…”

*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.raw_text: *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165 (1973)
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.proposition: Defendant knew or, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have known of the icy and dangerous condition of the sidewalk, particularly after receiving complaints and photographs from tenants, and thus had actual and/or constructive notice of the hazard.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.support_reasoning: The case does not involve ice, tenant complaints, photographs, or prior reports of the hazardous condition. Instead, it concerns a foreign substance on subway stairs and whether there was sufficient circumstantial evidence that it had been present long enough to give the defendant constructive notice. The opinion discusses general premises-liability notice principles and the time element, but it does not address actual notice through complaints or photographs, nor does it hold that such facts establish actual or constructive notice of an icy sidewalk condition.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.relevant_excerpt: “Where a foreign substance on a floor or stairway causes the business visitor to fall and sustain injuries, he may prove the negligence of the defendant by proof that the defendant or his servant caused the substance to be there, or he may show that the defendant or his servants had actual knowledge of the existence of the foreign substance… In the more usual case, however, the plaintiff attempts to establish the defendant’s negligence by showing that the foreign substance was present… for such a length of time that the defendant should have known about it.”

See *Janosz v. J.C. Penney Co.*, 324 Mas.raw_text: See *Janosz v. J.C. Penney Co.*, 324 Mass. 394 (1949).
See *Janosz v. J.C. Penney Co.*, 324 Mas.proposition: The risk that a person lawfully using the sidewalk—such as a tenant, guest, mail carrier, or delivery driver—would slip and fall on the ice was foreseeable.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Under G.L. c. 231, § 85, Plaintiff’s potential comparative negligence, if any, does not bar recovery so long as her negligence, if any, was not greater than the total negligence of the Defendant, and any recovery may only be reduced in proportion to Plaintiff’s percentage of fault.

See *O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw*, 431 Mass..raw_text: See *O’Sullivan v. Shaw*, 431 Mass. 201 (2000) (duty to act reasonably in light of foreseeable risks).
See *O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw*, 431 Mass..proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries and damages are the kind of harm that is reasonably foreseeable from failing to properly clear, sand, salt, or maintain a sidewalk subject to melting and refreezing, after a snowstorm, especially where the owner has been warned of the dangerous condition and chooses not to act.
See *O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw*, 431 Mass..support_reasoning: This case concerns the open and obvious danger doctrine and a landowner’s duty (or lack thereof) to warn about an obvious risk of diving into the shallow end of a swimming pool. It does not deal with snow, ice, sidewalks, melting/refreezing conditions, or with an owner’s duty after being warned of an icy condition. The opinion is about when no duty exists because harm is not reasonably foreseeable from an open and obvious condition, not about foreseeability of harm from negligently maintained icy walkways, so it does not support the stated sidewalk/ice proposition.
See *O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw*, 431 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises. This duty includes an obligation to ‘maintain[ ] his property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk’ … However, a landowner’s duty … ordinarily does not extend to dangers that would be obvious to persons of average intelligence.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B and 60F.proposition: Medical expenses, including charges for evaluation, treatment, and related care, in the approximate amount of $1,200.00, and such additional medical expenses as may be incurred in the future, pursuant to G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B and 60F;

Under G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B,.proposition: Under G.L. c. 231, § 6B, Plaintiff is entitled to prejudgment interest on the damages awarded for her personal injuries from the date the action is commenced.

Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825 (19.proposition: Under Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368 (2010), and cases applying it (including, e.g., Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825 (1994), Aylward v. McCloskey, 412 Mass. 77 (1992), and Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988)), Massachusetts courts recognize that property owners and persons in control may be held liable in negligence for failing to use reasonable care to prevent or remedy dangerous snow and ice conditions on property they control, and Plaintiff’s claim is consistent with this body of law.
Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825 (19.support_reasoning: This case applies the pre‑Papadopoulos natural‑accumulation rule and holds that a property owner (here, a town) is *not* liable for failing to remove or sand a natural accumulation of snow and ice. The court explicitly rejects the argument that the town had an affirmative duty to remove or sand the naturally accumulated ice on the ramp. Papadopoulos later overruled this doctrine, so Sullivan does not stand as authority that owners may be held liable for failing to use reasonable care to prevent or remedy dangerous snow and ice conditions; it is instead an example of the older, more restrictive rule Papadopoulos displaced.
Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825 (19.relevant_excerpt: “In our most recent decision addressing an owner’s duty with regard to snow and ice, we made clear that this duty is not violated by a failure to remove a natural accumulation of snow or ice. Aylward v. McCloskey, 412 Mass. 77, 80 (1992). … Liability is possible only ‘in circumstances where some act or failure to act has changed the condition of naturally accumulated snow and ice….’ … [T]he evidence indicates only that the ice on which the plaintiff fell was a natural accumulation. The situation is, therefore, governed by the Aylward decision, where there can be no liability….”

Aylward v. McCloskey, 412 Mass. 77 (1992.proposition: Under Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368 (2010), and cases applying it (including, e.g., Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825 (1994), Aylward v. McCloskey, 412 Mass. 77 (1992), and Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988)), Massachusetts courts recognize that property owners and persons in control may be held liable in negligence for failing to use reasonable care to prevent or remedy dangerous snow and ice conditions on property they control, and Plaintiff’s claim is consistent with this body of law.
Aylward v. McCloskey, 412 Mass. 77 (1992.support_reasoning: This case applies the pre-Papadopoulos “natural accumulation” rule and holds that the defendants could not be found negligent for failing to remove a natural accumulation of snow and ice. The court affirms summary judgment for the landowners because natural accumulations are not, by themselves, actionable defects absent some additional negligent act or condition, which is the opposite of the post-Papadopoulos rule that imposes a duty of reasonable care with respect to snow and ice. Although the opinion contains dicta recognizing that snow and ice can sometimes be a hazardous condition, its holding does not support the proposition that owners may be liable for failing to use reasonable care to prevent or remedy dangerous natural snow and ice conditions; instead, it rejects such liability on these facts.
Aylward v. McCloskey, 412 Mass. 77 (1992.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiffs wrongly conclude, however, that the defendants breached this duty by failing to remove a natural accumulation of snow and ice on their property. The duty of reasonable care ‘does not make landowners and occupiers insurers of their property nor does it impose unreasonable maintenance burdens.’ … There is no evidence in this case which would allow a jury to find that the defendants failed to exercise reasonable care in the circumstances and created a defective condition on their property. In the absence of such evidence, there is no evidence of negligence by the McCloskeys.”

Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.proposition: Under Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368 (2010), and cases applying it (including, e.g., Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825 (1994), Aylward v. McCloskey, 412 Mass. 77 (1992), and Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988)), Massachusetts courts recognize that property owners and persons in control may be held liable in negligence for failing to use reasonable care to prevent or remedy dangerous snow and ice conditions on property they control, and Plaintiff’s claim is consistent with this body of law.
Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.support_reasoning: This case is about a wrongful-death negligence claim arising from an allegedly unsafe freight elevator, not from snow or ice conditions. Although the opinion recites the general duty of a landowner to maintain property in a reasonably safe condition, it ultimately finds no negligence and nowhere discusses or applies any rule concerning snow and ice. It therefore does not specifically support the proposition that Massachusetts courts hold property owners liable for failing to use reasonable care to prevent or remedy dangerous snow and ice conditions.
Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.relevant_excerpt: “Clearly, the law imposed on this defendant a duty to maintain his property ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ Mounsey v. Ellard, supra… The question to be decided, then, is whether the jury reasonably could have concluded that, in view of all the circumstances, an ordinarily prudent person in the defendant’s position would have taken steps, not taken by the defendant, to prevent the accident that occurred.”

G.L. c. 261.proposition: Costs of this action as allowed by law, pursuant to G.L. c. 261 and applicable rules;

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 60 and applicable Massachusetts Rules of Civil Procedure, Plaintiff hereby demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.
